description.narrative: Landscape Conservation Areas established ensuring that land uses in areas adjacent to existing Protected Areas are compatible with biodiversity conservation objectives.
desert
Environment - policy, planning and administration
Five (5) Landscape Conservation Areas (LCA) in place and fully functional/operational by 2014

comment.narrative: Landscape management remains uncoordinated and biodiversity is lost over time. Current METT scores as follows: ML (71) GWL (69), GSNL (37), GFRCL (46), WGB (30): average: 51.

1) Framework for the establishment of landscapes and formalization of the existing PLCAs developed 2) 5 LCAs formalised and boundaries agreed 3) LCAs strategic management plan approved 4) Adaptive collaborative management committees in place and operational in LCAs 5) LCA infrastructure in place 6) Biodiversity status/pressure indicators and management objectives integrated into national tourism venture certification system 7) Supply chains established for game produced under BD friendly production systems

description.narrative: Establish new Landscape Conservation Areas LCAs

Constitutions in place for 5 landscapes
The indicator and target on Partnership agreements in place for 5 landscapes Constitutions in place for 5 landscapes was changed to Constitutions in place for 5 landscapes and 5 LCAs with constitutions in place for 5 landscapes respectively MTR recommendations This indicator has been achieved but the terminology should be changed as appropriate to remain consistent with clear definitions eg partnership agreements vs constitutions

comment.narrative: Constitutions in place for conservancies and drafts for GWC GSNC and GFRCC
5 landscapes with approved constitutions in place by year 5

Partially acheived The projet has revised Landscape Conservation Area constitutions following the decision by the Ministry of Environment and Tourism management not to sign the constitutions pending the finalization of the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Bill Based on the Implementation Guidelines for the National Policy on Protected Areas Neighbours and Resident Communities constitutions will be signed by landscape stakeholders or the Landscape Conservation Area Association excluding the Ministry of Environment and Tourism Once the consititutions are signed the association will enter into a Memorandum of Unerstanding with the Ministry of Environment and Tourism for the management of the respective protected areas and adjacent land as a single landscape conservation area

description.narrative: Infrastructure based on approved recommended priorities are in place for 5 landscapes

comment.narrative:
Mudumu fire management equipment water points GWC guard posts boundary fences fire management equipment water points WGB park and farm fences water points guard post at DVJ GSNC fences water points guard post GFRCC fences water points guard posts solid waste management and Radio communication at AiAis
Updated in 2013 at Project Steering Committee based on needs assessment

All infrastructure is in place for all landscapes based on assessment by December 2015
The target on Infrastructure is in place for all LCAs based on assessment by year 5 was changed to Infrastructure is in place for all LCAs based on assessment by December 2015 MTR recommendations This indicator is suitable no suggested changes but to reiterate that the infrastructure should be relevant to the goal and objectives of the project All infrastructure should be in place by Dec 2015

Partially achieved In addition to the already developed infrastructure in various landscapes the project developed further infrastructure such as the a infrastructure supporting the Khomas Hochland Hiking Trail in Windhoek Green Belt Landscape Conservation Areas and b tourist game viewing hide at Santika Waterpoint in Mudumu Landscape Conservation Area Other infrastructure development yet to be completed include the upgrading of the Sesriem Gate in Greater SossusvleiNamib Landscape to reduce dawn bottlenecks and office accommodation for the 4 Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area conservancies

description.narrative:
Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined setting the scene to develop regulations standards and codes of practice Regulations standards and codes of practice developed for each landscape National level best practice codes of practice in place
The indicator and target on Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined setting the scene to develop regulations standards and codes of practice Standards and codes of practice developed for each LCA National level best practice codes of practice in place was split into the following indictors and targets Indicator Standards and codes of practice developed for each Landscape Conservation Area and Target Standards and codes of practice developed for each LCA by Dec 2014 and Indicator National level best practice codes of practice in place and Target National level best practice codes of practice in place by Dec 2015 MTR recommendations There are four components each with a different output to this indicator
i identification of the threats at a landscape level already done at PPG stage
ii defining sustainable land uses in each LCA already done to some extent at PPG stage but this should be included in the LCA management plans
iii developing standards and codes for each LCA these have been done to some extent already but guidelines and regulations for each LCA building on the constitutions and management plans still need to be done and
iv Publishing the best practice codes at a national level
Thus the first two are not relevant as they were done in the PPG stage
We recommend that the standards and codes akin to guidelines and regulations are developed for each LCA with a target date of Dec 2014 those in the GW LCA will be developed later once the issues in this area are sorted out
Standards and codes at a national level should then be finalised by Dec 2015

Biodiversity threats defined for all landscapes

Park specific regulations in place which parks

Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined by year 5 landscape level regulations standards and codes of practice for biodiversity conservation in place by year 5 National level codes of practice based on best practice in place by year 5
Partially acheived The development of code of practice to be done upon completion of the development of the National Level Best Practices

description.narrative: National level best practice guidelines in place for the establishment of LCAs

comment.narrative: Draft MET Protected Area management planning policy guideline in place

National level best practice guidelines for the establishment of new landscapes in place by April 2015
The target on National level best practices guidelines for the establishment of new LCAs in place by year 5 was changed to National level best practices guidelines for the establishment of new LCAs in place by April 2015
MTR recommendation This indicator is suitable we recommend changing the target date to April 2015 as the LCAs have been established and the guidelines can now be written and approved
PSC The timeframe was endorsed as recommended

The Project is developing lessons learned challenges and best practices in the establishment of landscape conservation areas in Namibia To ensure objectiveness of the process the project contracted a consultant to develop these practices Furthermore the project is arranging to host a National Workshop to Share the experience In addition to the development of these lessons learned challenges and best practices the project has show cased the project at various global stages that include the IUCN World Parks Congress in Sydney Australia and the World Bank Annual Conference on Land and Policy in Washington DC USA

description.narrative: Incentives and market transformation

SPAN Biodiversity indicators being developed at present

NBSAP in place with biodiversity management objectives national level
Local level monitoring LLM systems in place at conservancy level incident monitoring books in place for parks
CPP integrated sustainable land management indicators and Land Degradation Monitoring System LDMS with biodiversity indicators
Biodiversity monitoring indicators in place by year 5 for each landscape and across landscapes

Partially Achieved Different landscapes are at different stages of developing monitoring systems Mudumu Landscape has a welldeveloped integrated system within protected areas and conservancies that uses the Incident and Event Book Monitoring systems The Greater SossusvleiNamib Namib has developed a Game Count Data Management System for an Integrated Monitoring System for the stakeholders The first Integrated Landscape Game Count was undertaken across all properties on 20 June 2015 Similarly the Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape is mirroring efforts from the Greater SossusvleiNamib Landscape

description.narrative: Supply chains developed based on current and potential markets for the diversification of current goods and services and or the development of new ones Supply chains identified for certification Markets established and mobilised for certified supply chains

Cheetahfriendly beef initiative that could be used for lessons learnt and best practices

Ongoing The project has supported the diversification of current goods and services within landscapes These include a Enhancing the Klein Karas Community resilience to effects of climate change through a community Garden b Production of tourist products by Women Sewing Project of Klein Karas Community in Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape and c Diversifying livelihood among stakeholders in Windhoek Green Belt Landscape through development of Khomas Hochland Hiking Trail and d Development of new tourism route in Mudumu Landscape Conservation Area

description.narrative:
Landscape Conservation Areas LCAs are established and ensure that land uses in areas adjacent to existing Protected Areas are compatible with biodiversity conservation objectives and corridors are established to sustain the viability of wildlife populations GEF 45 mill USD
This resolution was reached at inception meeting for landscape not to pursue protected areas status due to realities on the ground influenced by the land reform program in the country
5 landscapes are established to improve biodiversity conservation at landscape level an additional 15550 km2 brought under collaborative management with protected areas

comment.narrative: 4 existing landscape conservation partnerships in place
5 landscapes established by year 5 with at least 15550 km2 additional land under collaborative management with protected areas being ML 1469 GWL 7500 GSNL 173 GFRCL 5750 WGB 658
Achieved during the reporting period of 2012 The area protected by the established LCAs of 35049km significantly exceeds the targeted 15550km

description.narrative:
Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created
The indicator and target on Trends in increased abundance and distribution of selected species was changed to Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created MTR recommendation What may be more important than the abundance estimates which are unlikely to change significantly over the course of this project are i the changes in the movement patterns of animals particularly in those areas in which the fences have been removed as may be measured through distance travelled by andor home range sizes of collared animals using the data that is already being collected and ii changes if any in the use of corridors by animals usually using data from collared animals
Although the change was endorsed the Project Steering Committee felt that due to the high costs associated with wildlife movement research using collars the project is to use existing data

comment.narrative:
Key species collared to monitor wildlife movement in Mudumu and Greater SossusvleiNamib Landscapes
Baseline changed from Abundance estimates for game in place at conservancy and park level Mudumu Landscape excluding Mamili Buffalo 1 214 Giraffe 205 Impala 6 795 Wildebeest 2 305 Source September 2011 Dry Season Count MET NACSO Greater Sossusvlei Landscape Naukluft Mountains part of the Namib Naukluft Park Mountain Zebras 2 600 Source June 2013 Aerial Survey MET Greater Waterberg Landscape Waterberg Plateau Park Buffalo 550 Roan Antelope 180 Sable Antelope 100 Source September 2012 helicopter survey MET Windhoek Green Belt Landscape Daan Viljoen Game Park Oryx 150 Zebras 180 Source MET estimates onlyto Key species collared to monitor wildlife movement in Mudumu and Greater SossusvleiNamib Landscapes
PSC The change was endorsed However the Committee felt that due to the high costs associated with wildlife movement research using collars the project is to use existing data
Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created

Partially achieved There is strong evidence that wild animals are inreasingly using corridors created within Landscapes Conservation Areas Various Landscape Conservation Areas have shown varrying degrees on corridor usage Research on wildlife movement using sattelite collars on key species in Mudumu Landscape have shown the usage of corridors with the landscape and wildlife dispersal between Botswana Namibia Angola and Zambia Similar trend has energed in the Greater SossusvleiNamib Landscape Conservation Area where preliminary results from the research on wildlife movement have shown fences obstructing wildlife movement and unobstructed movement where fences have been removed or are poorly maintained In Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape Conservation Area the annual game census carried out on the Gondwana Private Nature Reserve within the landscape has shown fluctuating population numbers of Mountain Zebra compared to previous annual censuses suggesting that they are moving within the AiAis Hot Springs Game Park and adjacent land particularly where fences were removed or poorly maintained due to the rugged terrain

description.narrative: Framework in place for collaborative management among stakeholders within landscapes

comment.narrative: Draft MET Protected Area management planning policy guideline in place
Framework for collaborative management among stakeholders within landscapes targeted 5 landscapes in place by year 5

Partially achieved The National Policy on Protected Areas Neighbours and Resident Communities was approved by Cabinet and officially launched It became the legislation in Namibia that recognizes landscapes Conservation Areas Further to the policy The MET with project support developed Implementation Guidelines for the effective implementation of the policy The policy will pave way for inclusion of landscape conservation into the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Bill being developed with support from the project

description.narrative:
METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level
The indicator and target on Improved systems level operations capacity has ensured a reduced level of threats to habitats and species composition Landscapes maintain global biodiversity values METT scores are improved in protected areas within landscapes was changed to METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level
MTR Recommendation We propose that this indicator is reduced to one that focuses exclusively on the METT scores both at the landscape level ie for each LCA but also within each of the statemanaged protected areas ie there should be a METT score for each LCA and for the statemanaged PA in each area
The aspects of species diversity should be removed it has not been monitored to date there is no baseline and anyway the project is unlikely to influence species diversity over its lifetime except perhaps an agreement to remove all exotic species from the LCAs

comment.narrative: Landscape management remains uncoordinated and biodiversity is lost over time Current METT scores as follows ML 71 GWL 69 GSNL 37 GFRCL 46 WGB 30 average 51
METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level
The METT assessment is planned for second half of 2015 The METT assessment carried out in 2013 for the MTR showed an increase by 12 in the average score across the five landscapes

NB Revision of Indicator targets As per the findings of the MidTerm Review these indicators were overambitious and cannot be achieved during the project timeframe Indeed it is logically impossible to expect a project to achieve postproject emission reductions by the end of the project The indicators were not sufficiently amended to reflect the project redesign requested by GEFSec during the protracted project preparation phase Specifically the indicators do not accurately reflect the revised goal of the project which is to have the feasibility study for a CSP plant in place by the end of the project not to construct the plant itself

Strengthening the Capacity of the Protected Area System to Address New Management Challenges (PASS Namibia)
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: The project targets to strengthen the systems of Protected Areas in Namibia.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration
1. Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

comment.narrative: 1. CDI Score for PA at three levels: Systemic: 72% Institutional: 59% Individual: 56%

Protected areas system sustainability enhanced through improved capacity for detection, monitoring and cost effective enforcement.
Provide Support to the poaching incidences, as part of individual, institutional and systemic capacity strengthening work of the PASS Project.

Protected areas system and institutional sustainability enhanced through improved capacity for detection, monitoring and cost effective anti-poaching enforcement.
The project has organised a National Fire Management Conference envisaged for 2016 (together with NAFOLA, a sister project with the Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry). The aim of the National Conference is to bring together all fire stakeholders (the government institutions, Park managers, community members, farmers, Universities and other research institutions, municipalities, fire experts etc) to analyze the fire management approaches and come up with National Recommendations.
Pending the National Conference and review of each PA's SOP, the project has embarked upon the strengthening of current fire management practices. Namely: (a) Introduction of Early Burning to minimize plant biomas / fire load as a strategy to counter adverse fire impacts during the fire season, (b) maintenance of fire-breaks and (c) creation of new fire breaks - where necessary, to contain, limit and confine fire outbreaks to smaller areas / burned patches at a time. For the reporting period, these activities were implemented in the project intervention sites. i.e Waterberg (40,500 ha), Etosha (2,227,000 ha), Khaudum (384,000 ha) and Bwabwata (610,000 ha) = 3,261,500 ha in total.
During the ME assessment of project activities against the SRF, it was discovered that the SRF in the Project Document was incomplete (omission during the formulation of the project document and misunderstanding re the inception work to complete the baselines). The incomplete SRF made it difficult to properly track progress, because some mid-term and end-term targets were missing and some targets did not have baseline data etc. During the reporting period, the project has been working with the UNDP country office (UNDP-CO) and the UNDP Regional Technical Centre (RTC) for Africa (based in Ethiopia) to find the missing information and
One (1) Automated revenue collection system introduced and piloted in the Etosha to build a database, track, monitor, and reconcile PA fees and PA entrances and exits

One (1) Automated Revenue Collection System established and piloted at four gates/entrances and exits of the Etosha National Park. Despite the fact that 4 x gate systems and 3 x pay-point system are functional and generate park entry permits daily, the system is experiencing challenges with transmission lines, which are independently set up and run by the national mobile tele communication (MTC) company.

description.narrative: To Strengthen and sustainably finance the PAS through improved current systems for revenue generation introduction of innovative revenue generation mechanisms and cost effective enforcement through application of the Enforcement Economics Model

description.narrative: Implementation of the Integrated Fire Management Strategy
8 Number of hectares under improved integrated fire management

comment.narrative: SOPs are currently not in place
100 of Namibias PAs 135906 ha

National Fire Management Strategy developed and approved
ToR for development of SOP for each PA finalized
Improved Fire Management practices Namely a Introduction of Early Burning to minimize biomas fire load as a strategy to counter adverse fire impacts during the fire season b maintenance of firebreaks and c creation of new fire breaks where necessary to contain limit and confine fire outbreaks to smaller areas burned patches at a time For the reporting period these activities were predominantly implemented in Etosha 2227000 ha Khaudum 384000 ha and Bwabwata 610000 ha 3221000 ha in total

title.narrative: Sustainable Management of Namibia's Forested Lands (NAFO

description.narrative: Current dry forests and the ecosystem goods and services in 13 Community Forests maintained through legalization of Community Forests. Adaptation of Sustainable Land and Forest Management supported.

title.narrative: Mid Term Review: Sustainable Management of Namibia’s Forested Lands Project (NAFOLA)
UPDATING OF THE MONITORING AND EVALUATION (M&E) FRAMEWORK FOR THE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF NAMIBIA?S FORESTED LANDS (NAFOLA) PROJECT AND TRAINING OF STAFF ON RESULTS BASED MANAGEMENT (RBM)

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Current dry forests and the ecosystem goods and services in 13 Community Forests maintained through legalization of Community Forests. Adaptation of Sustainable Land and Forest Management supported.
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Activities of the project are taken place in 12 Community Forest hot spots in 7 regions in Namibia.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Increased area of gazetted community forests within the CF hotspots in northern Namibia with legal management structures.
2. Number of national, local and regional dialogue forums actively supporting implementation of policy recommendations of the CPP in local SFM and SLM processes.

comment.narrative:
1. 3 out of 13 CFs gazetted; some identified/ established communal forests but without any systematic management regime or formalised authority.
2. No regional and national level production sector frameworks incorporating forestry issues - 1 (Ministerial Forum)

Output 1: 1. Documents for 3 CFs submitted for gazettment 2. IFPMs for 2 gazetted CF finalised and 3 for emerging CFs 3. 120 communities trained to support CF activities 4. Strategies to integrate Conservancies in two hotspots
Output 2: 1. Regional CA Forum established in Omaheke. Demo plots established in Epukiro 2. Implementation of relevant strategies to enhance rangeland conditions and livestock take-off (guided by baseline assessment). 3. Establish monitoring programme and train communities to carry out monitoring for ongoing construction of auction kraal in Talismanus 4. Implement income generation activities in line with baseline assessment and set up a monitoring system 5. Finalize Fire Management Policy 6. At least 1 pilot project for bush control set up (for feed and energy production) 7. Conduct baseline on energy consumption and develop strategies to reduce pressure on forest resources 8. Finalize monitoring system for project and prepare 1st PIR

Training on the following topics for the Directorate of Forestry (DoF) and Project Liaison Officers (PLOs)delivered: • Milestones for gazetting • Inventory methods and tools • Participatory rural appraisal • Writing scientific reports • Developing management plans Staff members of the DoF, Directorate of Agricultural Engineering and Extension Services (DAPEES) and PLOs were trained on methods to assess rangeland and livestock conditions.
13 CFs were assessed in regards to the stage of gazettment they were in, February 2015. 4 were found to have been gazetted prior to the start of NAFOLA project. 7 were found to be at stage one of gazetting (i.e. interest in gazetting registered with the Directorate of Forestry). 2 were found to be on the second stage of gazetting where interim committees were set up and discussions on indicative land uses and resource mapping initiated. As a result of the assessment, 13 work plans were developed and are being updated annually.
Community forest boundaries were agreed upon in 8 CFs. In one of the CF there are local unresolved disputes over the CF boundaries (Ongandjera). Such disputes will need to be resolved prior to the submission of the dossiers for gazetting.

1. Increased area of gazetted community forests within the CF hotspots in northern Namibia with legal management structures
2. Forest sector issues reflected in regional land use plans and regional programs of sectors such as agriculture, water, local development, environment and tourism.
3. Number of national, local and regional dialogue forums actively supporting implementation of policy recommendations of the CPP in local SFM and SLM processes.

1. One CF has been successfully gazetted; Dossiers for 7 CFs have been technically finalized and are undergoing the legislative process for gazetting within the Ministry of Justice. Dossiers for the 2 remaining CFs will be finalized by end of 2017 and submitted for gazetting in early 2018.
2. Two sector considers forestry issues; i.e. the National Agricultural Policy that promotes protection and conservation of indigenous plants and genetic material and agroforestry. ; and the Renewable Energy Policy of 2017 supports the use of biofuels, with specific reference to invader bush. It advocates for the development of a biofuel policy by 2025.
3. Target fully achieved. Conservation Agriculture Forums ( one at national and 2 at regional level)

description.narrative: % (or number of) of households that have more secure access to livelihood assets (5 point score) in the target regions, Disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: Farmers (women and men) currently constrained by limited access to CCA knowledge and resilient agricultural practices

-Smallholder advisory and mentorship programme initiated -Conservation Agriculture (CA) practices promoted and adopted -Water conservation measures, e.g. Micro-drip irrigation installations explored -School gardens and drought/flood control and management measures, including hand dung wells implored and -Development of Climate change adaptation ME system to report adaptation practices on the ground developed

1. Smallholder advisory and mentorship programme that promotes drought resilient land management and crop production practices to scale up good practice for 4,000 smallholder farmers implemented 2. Community self‐help groups (SHGs) formed in the project zones to promote implementation and replication of climate‐smart methods including sustainable community financing and saving schemes scaled up and supported 3. At least 300 farmers’ field school leaders and coordinators in drought resilient land management and Conservation Agricultural, including climate smart practices trained to further serves/provide mentorship and training to 4,000 households in the project zones/regions 4. About three market linkages for dryland products and ‘fresh’ produces working with the private sector, through AMTA established 5. Documentation of best practices with not less than 3 lessons on the climate change adaptation captured and shared in 2017, one contributed to the Adaptation Learning Mechanism (ALM) 6. A detailed gender assessment with a full analytical report conducted for the current phase of project (implementation) by end of 2017. 7. Annual PIR/APR by June and Annual Report by November capturing progresses attained by end of 2017. 8. Updated ME Framework with all indicators completed and data disaggregated and analysed by gender, including logframe, AMAT and other tools being used for ME for the project, esp. as contribution to the National Implementing Agencies (i.e. MET and MAWF) reporting requirements

Smallholder advisory and mentorship programme initiated with these yearly outputs met: --Literature review on Climate Change Adaption Strategy in Namibia – Promoting Conservation Agriculture and Resilience --Capacity assessment report for the smallholder advisory and mentorship programme --Draft manuals incorporating the gaps identified in the literature review and the capacity assessment on the Smallholder advisory and mentorship programme submitted covering:  Mentoring;  Climate change;  Conservation Agriculture;  Micro-drip Irrigation;  Self-help Groups;  Access to Finance
Documentation of best practices on climate change adaptation (CCA) captured and shared in 2017, o --Presentation of lessons learnt and best practices delivered at the following fora: o MAWF Planning Workshop, Rundu o International Conference on Agriculture and Natural Resources - (ICANR 2017) - Faculty of Agriculture and Natural Resources (FANR) of the University of Namibia (UNAM), Ogongo o CRAVE Project Staff Induction Workshop – MAWF, Windhoek o National Horticulture Day – Okahandja o UNFCCC side-event – Bonn, Germany

description.narrative: 1. Number of project document developed (2016) 2. Number of tour visits conducted ( 2016) 3. Number of stakeholder meetings conducted (2016) 4. No of policy briefs developed (2016-2017) 5. No of poverty eradication programmes developed (2017) 6. No of reports produced (2017) 7. No of Trainer of Trainer workshops on GRB refresher tools

comment.narrative:
4. 3 5. 2 6. 1 7. 0
First training was undertaken in April 2017. The training programme was designed to assist participants in producing empirically sound and policy-relevant socioeconomic research based on available Namibian data. Two broad goals were pursued: (1) get participants to understand and practically apply appropriate techniques for analyzing sociology-economic issues using Namibian micro data in Stata and (2) enable participants to communicate their empirical findings effectively through the medium of policy briefs.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

BCC has full staff complement
Single work-plan road-map
Successful pilot project completed with communities and private sector
Capacity Development Trackers
Clear records of successful investments and returns from stress reduction activities by various stakeholders
Approximately 5,000 linear km of Coastline in the LME under ICM and MSP and contributing to preventing further loss and degradation in most significant marine protected areas
Approximately 1,000 sq. km identified and/or designated as EBSAs and/or MPAs with formal management processes and mechanisms in place
BCC provides improved management to 100% of the coastline through SAP implementation and BC Convention

comment.narrative: A Benguela Current Commission has been formally adopted as has a Benguela Current Convention. BCC needs to be more appropriately structured and supported and needs stronger institutional and intersectoral representation at the national level. Both the BCC Implementation Plan and the Convention expectations need to be harmonised under one set of priorities and these need to drive and delivery actual stress reduction activities. Stronger stakeholder engagement in this process is essential for long term management of LME resources as is a long-term investment plan to support stress reduction improvements

BCC has full staff complement
One (1) Ministerial Conference held
One (1) Annual Scientific and Governance Forum held
Single work-plan road-map

By end of 2017, interviews for a Project Manager conducted, NUNVs hired, and Financial Manager; however, the BCC has not yet recruited the Project Manager.
One (1) Ministerial Conference, the 6th Ministerial Conference of the Benguela Current Convention (BCC) held on the 09 November 2017
One (1), the 7th Annual Science Governance Forum of the Benguela Current Convention (BCC) held on the 25-27 October 2017
There is no single work-plan road-map in place yet.
